dmca.title: RIAA Notice of Intent to Service Subpoena
dmca.body:
By E-Mail and Campus Mail

Directed to:  *

Re: RIAA Notice of Intent to Service Subpoena

Dear ,

Please be advised that Carnegie Mellon University ("CMU") has received from the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) a
notice of its intention to serve a subpoena on CMU pursuant to Section 512 of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, commanding
disclosure of your identity based on allegations that you have been using CMU's computer network to upload and download unlawfully
copyrighted works.  We are enclosing a copy of the notice for your reference.

It is CMU's policy to protect privacy rights to the fullest extent consistent with its obligations under law.  In non-emergency
circumstances, CMU will not produce the subpoenaed identity information until 14 days after receipt of a subpoena so that the
[student / faculty member / staff member] whose information is sought will have adequate opportunity to pursue any legal remedy that
maybe available to him or her.  We will notify you as soon as we receive the subpoena so that you may immediately contact your own
legal counsel.

In the interim, please be mindful of your obligations to preserve evidence as set forth in the enclosed notice.  Intentional
destruction of evidence may have severe consequences.

Please also be aware that CMU will independently investigate the allegations made in the notice to determine whether there has been
any violation of CMU's policies prohibiting the unlawful use of CMU's network.
If this proves to be the case, we will notify you of our intention to suspend your network privileges.  Please also be advised that
violations of CMU's computing policies may result in disciplinary action.

Based on registration and authentication information available to us, it is our understanding that the machine at issue in the
notice,

MACHINE NAME			MAC ADDRESS
		*

is owned by you.

If the machine listed is not owned by you, or if you have other questions regarding this matter, please contact Holly Hippensteel
(hbh@andrew.cmu.edu).


				Very truly yours,



				Acting Chief Information Security Officer
       				Information Security Office


--------------------------  Attachment below --------------------------

I am an attorney with the Recording Industry Association of America, Inc. ("RIAA").  The RIAA is a trade association whose member
record companies create, manufacture, and/or distribute approximately ninety percent (90%) of all legitimate sound recordings sold
and distributed in the United States.

Because many ISPs have requested that we give them advance notice, I am writing to alert you to a forthcoming subpoena that will be
served on you.  The subpoena will request the name, address, telephone number, e-mail address and MAC (Media Access Control) address
of a user, customer, or subscriber of your system or network who has infringed our members' copyrighted sound recordings.  For your
information, that user was located at the following IP address: * on 3/17/2005 at * a.m.(EST).

Our outside counsel will soon serve the subpoena on you.  Understand that you have a legal obligation to preserve all identifying
information of the user, customer or subscriber in the meantime.  Please take all steps to do so.

We have found that some ISPs choose to notify their users, customers or subscribers about impending subpoenas.  Should you choose to
do so, we ask that you please make this individual aware that he or she has a legal obligation to preserve evidence that relates to
our legal claims.  This means that, at a minimum, the individual must preserve the entire library of recordings made available for
distribution as well as any recordings that were downloaded.  Although the individual must preserve the recordings, in order to
